data.title: Steinway — CityNeighborhoods.NYC
data.meta_description: At the far northwestern corner of Queens is the the neighborhood of Ditmars-Steinway, along the East River. To the north is Riker’s Island, while LaGuardia Airport is to the east. Southern neighbors include East Elmhurst and Astoria.
data.text:
The Neighborhood

Ditmars-Steinway is a mostly residential neighborhood - aside from the electric company and many green lawns of park space. Here is where you will find the iconic Hell’s Gate Bridge, along with peerless views of Manhattan.

Ditmars-Steinway, located in the northwest corner of Queens, is a vibrant neighborhood that boasts a unique mix of cultures and lifestyles. Perhaps best known for its proximity to LaGuardia Airport, it is also famous for its historic architecture, diverse restaurants, and thriving nightlife. The area is home to Greek, Egyptian, and Mexican communities, among many others, and the streets are lined with shops selling everything from specialty foods to vintage clothing. The iconic Steinway & Sons piano factory still stands in the heart of the neighborhood, a testament to the area's rich cultural legacy. Whether you're looking for a quiet residential enclave or a bustling urban experience, Ditmars-Steinway has something for everyone.

Named after two prominent figures in New York City history, the neighborhood of Ditmars-Steinway in Queens, New York has a unique origin story. Around the turn of the 20th century, Albert Ditmars purchased a large parcel of land near what is now known as 23rd Avenue and Steinway Street. He intended to develop it as a residential area, and in order to attract buyers, he named the streets after influential figures in history, as well as local businessmen. One of those businessmen was William Steinway, the owner of the famous Steinway & Sons piano company. Steinway was so impressed with Ditmars' development that he invested in it himself, helping to ensure its success. Thus, the neighborhood of Ditmars-Steinway was born, a testament to the vision of two forward-thinking New Yorkers.

The neighborhood of Ditmars-Steinway, located in the Queens borough of New York City, has a rich history that dates back to the early 1900s. The area was originally developed as a residential community for German immigrants, who were drawn to the neighborhood's proximity to the Steinway & Sons piano factory. In fact, the neighborhood takes its name from both the factory and the factory's founder, William Steinway, who was instrumental in the neighborhood's development. Over the years, the neighborhood has seen many changes, including the influx of new immigrants from Italy, Greece, and South America, which has led to a diverse and vibrant community. Today, Ditmars-Steinway is known for its lively commercial district, historic homes, and strong community spirit.

Ditmars-Steinway is a vibrant neighborhood located in the northwest corner of Queens, New York City. With its strong cultural heritage and diversity, the neighborhood is home to a few major landmarks and attractions that are worth exploring. For music lovers, the Steinway Mansion on 41st Street is a must-visit destination. It is the birthplace of Steinway pianos and has now been converted into the Astoria Performing Arts Center. Another prominent attraction is the Steinway & Sons factory, where visitors can take a guided tour and see how these world-renowned pianos are crafted. Art enthusiasts can head to the Museum of the Moving Image, which showcases the history and evolution of film, television, and video, and offers interactive exhibits for all ages to enjoy. Additionally, Astoria Park, a massive park that boasts gorgeous views of the East River and Manhattan skyline, is perfect for relaxation, picnics, and outdoor activities. With its rich history and culture, Ditmars-Steinway neighborhood has something to offer for everyone.

Ditmars-Steinway, Queens has been home to several famous people over the years. One of the most notable residents is Tony Bennett, a legendary singer who was born and raised in the neighborhood. Bennett is known for his iconic song "I Left My Heart in San Francisco," and has won multiple Grammy Awards over the course of his career. In addition, comedian and actor Ray Romano grew up in the neighborhood before finding fame on the hit sitcom "Everybody Loves Raymond." Other notable residents include actor Telly Savalas and singer-songwriter Carole King. The neighborhood's rich cultural history continues to attract artists and performers from all over the world.
